label: Letter to Marianne Haskell from her uncle, Frederick Grimke, February 8, 1863
description: A letter from Frederick Grimke to Marianne Haskell referencing a letter to the editor of his published in "The Crisis" (an abolitionist magazine), a disease of the throat that he is suffering from, and alludes to the Civil War as decided on the side of the Confederacy.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: A letter from Frederick Grimke to Marianne Haskell referencing a letter to the editor of his published in "The Crisis" (an abolitionist magazine), a disease of the throat that he is suffering from, and alludes to the Civil War as decided on the side of the Confederacy.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Chillicothe 8 Feb. 1863

Dear Niece

I am glad you received the two
papers I sent you. Your verses were mislaid for a con-
siderable time, otherwise they would have been
published long before. The reason why my letter to
the editor of the crisis was published [without?] name is that a year
before I wrote to him in words of equal encour-
agement, but although he published my letter,
he abstained from inserting my name, remark-
ing that he regretted that he did not feel author-
ized to give it; although if he were at liberty
to do so, "it would be of great advantage to
them, inasmuch as the author enjoyed a nati-
onal reputation." In a postscript to my letter
this year therefore, I gave him full liberty
to publish with my name.- But I am total-
ly at a loss to know the meaning of your Mo-
ther, when she says that there are several num-
bers of my articles which I have never furn-
ished her with, and which she desires I

[End page 1]

should supply her with, in order to complete her
set. Most assuredly I have either given with my
own hands, or sent to her every one of the [articles?],
and she has acknowledged the receipt of every
one. The last eight I gave her with my own
hand in October, the few preceding, I gave her
in the October preceding, and the two first were
sent to her and the receipt of them was ack-
nowledged by letter. This complete the 14 Nos
and if any are missing, she must have mis-
laid, or lent them to some one. The two articles which
were published in Cincinnati prior to this series, I did not
send, because I had but one copy of each.
Sell your Aunt Angelina that I received her let-
ter a few days ago, and the linen the day be-
fore the date of her letter. As it turned out, it
came all in time, and I am only sorry I gave
her so much trouble.

I have not been able to find the paper contain-
ing the details of the condition of Camp Chose,
or I would send it to you; but the condition
of all is the same. That at Louisville it is
even said to be much worse.

But I have forgotten to mention, that I am
now belonging under an ugly disease of the
throat; what is termed [illegible]; so that it is
with great difficulty that I swallow. The

[End page 2]

remedy is a very simple one however; it consists
in introducing the [bougie?] down the whole 
[illegible] of the esophagus [nine [illegible]] repeatedly
when the stricture is [illegible]. But the incon-
venience in the mean time is very great, and
even painful. You might suppose, that the
introduction of the bougie, would itself
be painful. Not so however, strange as it may
seem for the diameter is nearly the same as
my little finger.

I am glad to hear you speak of the many fine
traits of character, you find in Stewart. He
will most assuredly grow up to be a most ex-
cellent, and intelligent man. I hope you
have read to him the eight articles I
left with your Mother last fall. I think [illegible]
will be listened to by him with great eager-
ness, and earnestness, and will [contribute?] to
to confirm the great change which has
taken place in his political sentiments.
And here let me request that your Mother
will not cut out my articles; but preserve
them as I gave them.

Nothing need be said of the war: the defeats
and disasters of the abolition army have
been so [illegible]; and the victories
of the Confederates, so repeated, and tri-
umphant; that every thing may now be consi-
dered as settled.

[Illegible] your affect. Uncle,
Frederick Grimke

[End page 3]

Winter commenced on the 2d of this month.

[To:] Mrs [Madeline?] Haskell
Perth Amboy
New Jersey

[Postmarked:] Chillicothe, Feb 9 

[End page 4]
